title: Ann Franks Day (Lady Ann Fenhoulet)
provenance_text:
Sir Joshua Reynolds [1723-1792]. Sir Thomas Baring [1772-1848], by 1845 until 1848 [1]; by descent to Thomas George Baring, 1st Earl of Northbrook [1826-1904], until 1904 [2]; by descent to Francis George Baring, 2nd Earl of Northbrook [1850-1929], until 1929; Florence Anita, Countess of Northbrook, his wife [1861-1946], London, 1929 until February 1938; Christie, Manson & Woods, London, June 11, 1937, no. 15 [3]; sold at Christie, Manson & Woods, February 25, 1938, no. 120 [4]; purchased by Markey, February 25, 1938 [5]. Symons Galleries, New York, NY, in April 1938 [6]. Charles J. Rosenbloom, Pittsburgh, until Appril 1, 1973; bequest to Museum, February 1974. 

NOTES:
[1]. See Graves and Cronin "A History of the Works of Sir Joshua Reynolds, P. R. A.", Volume 1, London, 1899. [2]. Edward Hamilton's "Catalogue Raisonné of the Engraved Works of Sir Joshua Reynolds, P. R. A.", London, 1884, p. 171 adds the following information about the portrait; "FENHOULET, LADY.  Painted 1760.  Damaged by fire; has been restored.  Lord Northbrook." [3]. Countess of Northbrook sale, entitled "Pictures by Old Masters" as "Portrait of Lady Anne Fenhoulet", bought in. [4]. "Important Ancient and Modern Pictures and Drawings" under the heading "The Property of a Lady". Annotated sales catalogues (E. Waterhouse) at Getty Research Institute identify the seller at the 1938 sale as Lady Northbrook. [5]. The buyer, "Markey" and purchase price,  £115, 10s., at the 1938 sale are from an annotated sales catalogue at the Frick Research Library. [6]. Reported and illustrated in "The Connoisseur", June 1938.
